cab.content: (THIS McUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HER BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENT)SECRET ^-- CABINET OFFICE , pC(54) 102 RECORD COPY COPY NO. 0^15TH MARCH, 1954CABINETEGYPT: DEFENCE negotiations note by the Secretary of State for Foreign affairs circulate herewith for the information of my colleagues the annexed brief record of an interview between the United States Ministerand Sir Harold Caccia, Deputy Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Office.A.E.Foreign Office, S.W.I.15TH MARCH, 1954.annex the United States Minister, after speaking about Persian oil,said that the Embassy had a message to deliver about Egypt on instructions from the State Department.20 It was that the State Department concurred with the views of theUnited States Ambassador in Cairo that we should get down to negotiationswith the Egyptians on the basis of the offer made by Nasser. Theirreasons for thinking this were:-(a) that time might be short before the election campaign got under way;(b) that we should capitalize the straits in whichthe Council of Revolutionary Command (C0R.C.)now found themselves; and(c) that, despite the weaknesses of the C.R.C., the alternatives seemed worse.3. The State Department had asked that the United states ambassador should himself deliver this message and express the hopethat Her Majesty's Government would take advantage of Nasser's offer.However, Mr. Aldrich was away in Paris until next Tuesday. HenceMr. Butterworthfs statement to me which, he said, he would follow up with Sir Ivone Kirkpatrick. Mr. Butterworth emphasized that this was an expression of the American view and was not meant in any way to be anattempt by the United States Government to bring pressure to bear on her Majesty's Government.H.A. CACCIA13TH MARCH, 1954,
